Chat.greetingText:
I want to grow with you
Teach me what you know

aiResponses.0: Oh, that's a really interesting topic! Can you tell me more?
aiResponses.1: Wow! I was curious about that too. Thanks!
aiResponses.2: I see! Let me verify my understanding. Is that related to any other concepts?
aiResponses.3: That's amazing! I'm impressed you know this. Other Crowdians will love it too.
aiResponses.4: Hmm... I might need to study that a bit more. Could you explain it further?
aiResponses.5: Got it! So to summarize, is this correct?
aiResponses.6: Oho, that's news to me! So fascinating!
aiResponses.7: Great explanation! I have a related question, want to hear it?
aiResponses.8: Thanks a million! I feel like I've leveled up thanks to you!
aiResponses.9: Hmm... tough topic. But your explanation is helping me get the gist of it!

help.title: Help
help.levelDesc: Earn XP through chatting and level up! Your character grows as your level increases.
help.fatigueDesc: Engaging in many conversations builds up fatigue. High fatigue will reduce the amount of XP earned.

kc_1.question: When does the cleanup function of useEffect in React execute?
kc_1.answerA: It only runs when the component unmounts. It cleans up resources set during mount.
kc_1.answerB: It runs both when dependencies change (re-render) and on unmount. The previous effect is cleaned up before the new one runs.

kc_2.question: What is 'Hoisting' in JavaScript?
kc_2.hint: Think about how variable and function declarations are processed.

kc_3.question: What is the biggest difference between Flexbox and Grid in CSS?
kc_3.answerA: Flexbox is for 1D layouts (row or column), Grid is for 2D layouts (rows and columns simultaneously).
kc_3.answerB: Flexbox is for older browser compatibility, and Grid is a complete superset of Flexbox.

kc_4.question: Compare the pros and cons of REST API and GraphQL.
kc_4.hint: Think about data fetching methods and over-fetching/under-fetching.

kc_5.question: What is the difference between interface and type in TypeScript?
kc_5.answerA: They are nearly identical, but interface supports declaration merging while type offers more freedom with unions/intersections.
kc_5.answerB: Interface can only be used for objects, and type can be used for all types, so type is always better.
